JUDGES: Alvina Gyulumyan;Corneliu Bîrsan;Egbert Myjer;Ján Šikuta;Josep Casadevall;Luis López Guerra;Nona Tsotsoria
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant association was established under NORP law in DATE and is registered in ORG .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant association was represented before the Court by Ms ORG , a lawyer practising in PERSON .
CARDINAL . The Government of GPE ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . The applicant is an association under the Associations of Citizens Act ( Law no . CARDINAL Coll . , as amended ) . It has its own legal personality , distinct from that of its members .

CARDINAL . The preamble to its constitution states that the applicant association regards a forest as a living being that commands adequate respect ( clause CARDINAL ) , that the applicant association was established in order to save the natural forests of the planet , and that that salvation constitutes an essential duty of the current generation to future generations ( clause CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . Pursuant to LAW of its constitution , the applicant association ’s mission is to put into practice the ideas mentioned above , inter alia , by :
- direct action aimed at preventing the destruction of natural forests in particular ;
- representation of the legally recognised interests of its members in proceedings that touch upon the mission of the applicant association ;
- entering into decision - making processes that have an impact on forest economy activities , above all the creation of forest economy planning ;
- assistance in the preparation of documentation to determine the long - term goals and tasks of the forest economy and thereby contribute to enhancing the role of forests ; and
- detection of , and adequate reaction to , incidents involving a threat to health , property , nature and the environment .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant association considers its to fall under the category of “ public ” and “ concerned public ” , that is to say public affected or likely to be affected by , or with an interest in , environmental decision - making , within the meaning of LAW CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW - making and ORG ( “ the FAC ” ) ( see “ Relevant international material ” below ) .
CARDINAL . The High Tatra is a mountain range on the border between GPE and GPE . It is part of the LOC , which , together with the NORP Tatra LOC , form ORG ( “ the TANAP ” ) .

CARDINAL . The TANAP and its territory are protected under the Nature and LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL Coll . , as amended ) ( “ the LAW ” ) and Government Directive no . QUANTITY , which established the TANAP .

CARDINAL . The forest , land and resources located in the TANAP are administered by PERSON lesy TANAP - u ( “ GPE TANAP ” ) , a body established by ORG and linked to the national budget ( príspevková organizácia ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE high winds in the area comprising the High Tatra caused substantial damage to the forest , inter alia in the areas comprising ORG of the PERSON and Tichá valleys .
CARDINAL . Various administrative proceedings were held , mainly under LAW and LAW ( Law no . PERSON . , as amended ) , in order to address the consequences of the disaster .

CARDINAL . The applicant association made a number of requests to various authorities responsible for environmental protection that it be informed of any proceedings pending before such authorities concerning the protection of the environment . These included a request in reliance on LAW , made on DATE to ORG ; a request in reliance on LAW , made on or DATE to ORG ( Obvodný úrad životného prostredia ) ; and a request in reliance on LAW , made on DATE to ORG ( ORG lesný úrad ) .

CARDINAL . As a result of the above - mentioned requests , the applicant association participated in some proceedings and sought to participate in others . Its participation was in the procedural capacity of a party ( účastník konania ) to or a participant ( zúčastnená PERSON ) in the proceedings , within the meaning of ORG DATE ( Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL Coll . , as amended ) ( “ the ORG ” ) . As a general rule , unlike a party to proceedings , a participant has no right of appeal .

CARDINAL . Further details concerning the applicant association ’s participation in the proceedings ensuing the natural disaster and the procedural status of parties and participants are set out below .

CARDINAL . On DATE the PERSON branch of the FAC TANAP applied for a general derogation from the protective conditions applicable to the environment in the High Tatra , with a view to addressing the effects of the disaster . In so doing they also sought to obtain approval under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(b ) of LAW ( as applicable at that time ) to interfere with forest coppice and to damage vegetation and soil cover in the areas affected by the disaster for the same purpose .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL ) of LAW , as applicable at that time , the applicant association had the status of a party to those proceedings . Following an amendment to LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , the procedural status of environmental associations such as the applicant association was reduced to that of a participant .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG of the Environment ( PERSON úrad životného prostredia ) ruled that the application of GPE TANAP was subject to an environmental impact assessment ( ORG ) under LAW ( Law no . PERSON . , as amended , which was replaced with effect from DATE by PERSON no . PERSON . ) and that the proceedings be stayed until GPE TANAP had submitted such an assessment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Prešov Regional Office of the Environment ruled that unless GPE TANAP submitted the final ORG by DATE , the proceedings would be discontinued .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Prešov Regional Office of the Environment discontinued the proceedings because ŠL TANAP had failed to submit the final ORG . The decision was upheld on DATE by ORG following an appeal by GPE TANAP .

CARDINAL . On DATE the LOC branch of LOC requested that the forestry authority concerned declare a state of emergency and take measures to reduce the risk of an outbreak of bark beetle in the forests of the PERSON and Tichá valleys .

CARDINAL . Had the applicant association been invited to take part in the proceedings , it would have enjoyed the procedural status of a participant under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ( Law no . PERSON . , as amended ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered LOC to carry out preventive measures under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(i ) of the Forests Act with a view to reducing the risk of the spread of bark beetle in the forest of PERSON , in particular by cutting down infected trees in the wooded area affected by the disaster .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant association was not involved in the proceedings . The decision became final on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant association challenged the decision of DATE by way of a complaint under LAW to ORG ( Ústavný súd ) .

CARDINAL . The applicant association argued that the impugned decision should have been preceded by a derogation from , or approval of , non - compliance with environment protection measures under LAW . If that had happened , the applicant association would have had the status of a party to the proceedings under LAW . However , the decision of DATE was taken without prior derogation or approval , and thus without the applicant association ’s involvement . This was contrary to the applicant association ’s right of access to court and justice , and to its constitutional right to a good environment .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared the complaint inadmissible . It found that LAW accorded the applicant association the procedural status of a participant in , and not a party to , the proceedings in question .

That being recognised , ORG observed that the applicant association had had the opportunity to seek recognition of its position as a participant under the terms of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) of LAW . However , it had failed to seize that opportunity as it had requested that it be informed of proceedings under LAW only on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , that is to say after the end of the proceedings ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . Furthermore , ORG noted that the applicant association had been directly concerned with the subject matter of the proceedings but had failed to assert a claim to that effect . If it had done so , it would have had the status of a party to the proceedings , which would have allowed it to challenge the impugned decision by lodging an administrative appeal and , as appropriate , seeking judicial review .

CARDINAL . Finally , ORG held that the right to a good environment applied only to individuals and not to legal entities such as the applicant association , which therefore could not assert that right .
The decision was served on the applicant association on DATE .

CARDINAL . The object of LAW is to determine the jurisdiction of the administrative and municipal bodies as well as the rights and duties of legal entities and individuals in protecting nature and landscape , with a view to contributing to the preservation of the diversity of conditions and forms of life on the LOC . It is also the object of the LAW to provide conditions for the sustaining , renewal and rational use of natural resources , protection of natural heritage , maintaining the character of landscape , and achieving and sustaining ecological stability ( section CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . Unless provided otherwise , proceedings under the LAW are subject to the ORG ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) ( see below ) .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL ) , as applicable until DATE , associations of citizens whose objective for DATE had been environmental protection had the status of parties to proceedings under the LAW , provided that they announced their participation within DATE of being informed of the proceedings .

CARDINAL . A group of Members of ORG submitted a bill that was enacted with effect from DATE ( Law no . PERSON . ) amending LAW , inter alia , so that associations of citizens referred to under section CARDINAL ) of the LAW would have the status only of participants in proceedings .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) , an association referred to in section CARDINAL ) can request that the authority concerned inform it of any administrative proceedings before that authority with potential implications for the protection of nature and the environment under the LAW . The authority is then duty bound to inform the association of any such proceedings within DATE of their commencement or , as the case may be , of the request .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG amended the environment legislation , including LAW . The amendment entered into force on DATE no . PERSON . Among other changes , environmental associations were again accorded the status of party to the proceedings ( amended section CARDINAL ) , ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) ) .

It was acknowledged that the purpose of this change was , inter alia , to ensure that such associations had access to remedies under LAW of LAW and that , until that time , the applicable rules of procedure had lacked provisions for such access . It was also observed that , following the judgment of ORG of ORG of DATE in case no . C-CARDINAL/CARDINAL ( see below ) , the jurisprudence of ORG had settled so as to interpret the applicable procedural rules in conformity with the NORP rules ( see judgment of ORG in case no . CARDINALSžpCARDINAL/CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) and to accord the associations in question the procedural status of parties ( see report on the bill by ORG of ORG of that ORG , together with ORG ) .

CARDINAL . The Forests Act defines forest land and its protection , determines the ownership of forest land and the use of forests , and governs professional management of forests , support for a sustainable forest economy , jurisdiction of the ORG administrative agencies and ORG supervision of forestry , and sets out sanctions for breaches of the LAW ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . The purpose of the LAW is to preserve , develop and protect forests , to create the economic conditions for a diverse , professional and sustainable forest economy , and to ensure that the interests of society and those of forest owners are in harmony ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .
CARDINAL . Unless provided for otherwise , proceedings under LAW are subject to the ORG ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) ( see below ) .

CARDINAL . Associations whose aim is linked to the use and protection of forest property are not parties to the proceedings . Nevertheless , they can act as participants in the proceedings provided that they announce their participation within DATE of being informed of the relevant proceedings ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . NORP Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) , an association referred to in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) can request that the authority concerned inform it of any administrative proceedings before that authority with potential implications for its interests , and the authority is duty bound to inform the association of any such proceedings within DATE of their commencement or , as the case may be , of the request .

CARDINAL . A party to proceedings is a person whose rights and legally protected interests or duties are to be the subject matter of the proceedings or whose rights , legally protected interests or duties can be directly affected by the decision . A person who claims that his or her rights , legally protected interests or duties would be affected by the decision may also be a party to the proceedings , unless and until the opposite is established ( Article CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE an amendment ( Law no . CARDINAL Coll . ) to LAW entered into force which , inter alia , introduced the procedural category of participant in the proceedings . Under LAW of the amended LAW , a lex specialis can stipulate the conditions in which someone other than a party to the proceedings has the right to take part in the proceedings in full or in part . That person is called a participant . Unless a lex specialis accords a participant further rights , his or her position is limited to the right to be notified when proceedings commence and of other submissions by the parties , the right to take part in an oral hearing and in an in situ inspection , and the right to adduce evidence and to add to the material underlying the decision .

CARDINAL . The explanatory report ( dôvodová správa ) on the amendment submitted with the bill suggested that the creation of the procedural category of participant in administrative proceedings had been in response to the existing practice whereby , in particular in the area of environmental protection , associations of citizens and associations of legal entities took part in proceedings . Due to the lack of an appropriate procedural framework , for practical reasons such associations had been given the status of parties to the proceedings . However , that was contrary to the rules concerning parties , because the rights and duties of such associations had not been decided upon in the proceedings . Participation in the proceedings of persons other than the parties was advisable and would be significantly more frequent , especially in proceedings that involved public or group interests , for example in the construction of major industrial enterprises , the use of genetic technologies and the licensing of public works .

CARDINAL . Chapter ( Časť ) CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure ( Law no . PERSON . , as amended ) governs the administrative judiciary . In accordance with its provisions , administrative tribunals review the lawfulness of decisions taken by public administrative authorities on the basis of administrative - law actions under LAW ) CARDINAL of that LAW and administrative - law appeals under LAW of that LAW .

CARDINAL . Judicial review of administrative decisions and procedures by way of administrative - law actions under LAW CARDINAL requires that the matter be resolved by a decision that has become final and binding ( právoplatnosť ) , after all ordinary remedies have been exhausted ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The parties to proceedings on administrative - law actions are the claimant and the defendant ( LAW ) , the former being the individual or the legal entity who alleges that , as a party to the relevant administrative proceedings , his , her or its rights have been restricted by the decision and conduct of an administrative authority . The claimant may , however , also file an administrative - law action on the grounds that he , she or it had not been treated as a party to the administrative proceedings in question when although he , she or it should have been ( LAW ) .
CARDINAL . Details concerning ORG are set out below . ORG GPE agreed to accede to ORG on DATE and declared that , under LAW , the LAW has priority over LAW .
CARDINAL . The Aarhus Convention was published in LAW under no . DATE and entered into force in respect of GPE on DATE .

CARDINAL . In an unrelated set of proceedings , relying on ORG , the applicant association of the present case sought recognition of its standing as a party to proceedings concerning the request of a hunting association for derogation from certain provisions of LAW . The applicant association was unsuccessful before CARDINAL administrative and CARDINAL judicial level of jurisdiction .
CARDINAL . The applicant association lodged an appeal with ORG . In dealing with that appeal , on DATE ORG asked ORG of ORG for a preliminary ruling on the following questions :

“ CARDINAL . Is it possible to recognise DATE and in particular LAW , given that the principal objective pursued by that international treaty is to change the classic definition of locus standi by according the status of a party to proceedings to the public , or the public concerned , as having the direct effect of an international treaty ( ‘ self - executing effect’ ) in a situation where ORG acceded to that international treaty on DATE but to date has not adopted Community legislation in order to transpose the treaty concerned into Community law ?

CARDINAL . Is it possible to recognise DATE and in particular LAW , which has become a part of Community law , as having the direct applicability or direct effect of Community law within the meaning of the settled case law of ORG ?

CARDINAL . If the answer to the first of the second question is in the affirmative , is it then possible to interpret LAW , given the principal objective pursued by that international treaty , as meaning that it is necessary also to include within the concept ‘ act of a public authority’ an act consisting in the delivery of decisions , that is to say , that the right of public access to judicial hearings intrinsically also includes the right to challenge the decision of an administrative body , the unlawfulness of which lies in its effect on the environment ?
CARDINAL . The request was registered under file no . C-CARDINAL/CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . On DATE Advocate General PERSON delivered an opinion with the following conclusions :
CARDINAL . I therefore suggest that , in answer to the questions referred by the [ ORG ] , the ORG should rule as follows :
( CARDINAL ) The questions referred are inadmissible except in so far as they relate to LAW .

( CARDINAL ) It is for the national courts to determine whether Article CARDINAL ) of ORG has direct effect within their own legal order in circumstances in which ORG acceded to that international treaty on DATE but to date has not adopted legislation in order to incorporate that specific provision of the treaty concerned into ORG law in respect of the obligations that it imposes on the Member GPE .

( CARDINAL ) Article CARDINAL ) of ORG should be interpreted as including within the concept of ‘ act of a public authority’ an act consisting of the delivery of a decision . The right of public access to judicial review , within the constraints permitted by LAW , includes the right to challenge a decision of an administrative body which is alleged to contravene provisions of the Member ORG ’s national law relating to the environment .
If the ORG should take the view that it has jurisdiction to rule on the direct effect of LAW :
( CARDINAL ) Article CARDINAL ) of ORG does not have direct effect as a matter of GPE law . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE the Grand Chamber of ORG of ORG delivered a judgment .
It held that

“ Article CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the Convention on access to information , public participation in decision - making and access to justice in environmental matters approved on behalf of ORG of DATE does not have direct effect in ORG law . It is , however , for the referring court to interpret , to the fullest extent possible , the procedural rules relating to the conditions to be met in order to bring administrative or judicial proceedings in accordance with the objectives of Article GPE ) of that convention and the objective of effective judicial protection of the rights conferred by ORG law , in order to enable an environmental protection organisation , such as LOC , to challenge before a court a decision taken following administrative proceedings liable to be contrary to ORG environmental law .

CARDINAL . On DATE , following the judgment of ORG of ORG of DATE ( see the preceding paragraph ) , ORG quashed the challenged administrative decisions and held that , on the basis of that judgment , and with a view to ensuring effective protection of the environment , the applicant association had the right of action against administrative decisions , which may be contrary to ORG law , and that , consequently , it was to be accorded the procedural status of a party ( file no . CARDINAL PERSON ) . This position has since become generally accepted .

CARDINAL . ORG for LOC “ Convention on Access to Information , Public Participation in Decision - making and Access to Justice in Environmental Matters ” ( ORG ) was adopted on DATE and entered into force on DATE .
In its Preamble , the Parties to the LAW , inter alia :
- recognise that

“ every person has the right to live in an environment adequate to his or her health and well - being , and the duty , both individually and in association with others , to protect and improve the environment for the benefit of present and future generations ”
- consider that

“ to be able to assert this right and observe this duty , citizens must have access to information , be entitled to participate in decision - making and have access to justice in environmental matters , and acknowledge[s ] in this regard that citizens may need assistance in order to exercise their rights ,
- recognise that

“ in the field of the environment , improved access to information and public participation in decision - making enhance the quality and the implementation of decisions , contribute to public awareness of environmental issues , give the public the opportunity to express its concerns and enable public authorities to take due account of such concerns ,
- and also recognise
“ the desirability of transparency in all branches of government and inviting legislative bodies to implement the principles of this LAW in their proceedings ” .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW defines its objective and provides as follows :

“ In order to contribute to the protection of the right of every person of present and future generations to live in an environment adequate to his or her health and well - being , each ORG shall guarantee the rights of access to information , public participation in decision - making , and access to justice in environmental matters in accordance with the provisions of this Convention . ”

CARDINAL . Pursuant to LAW and DATE , which contain definitions , “ public ” means CARDINAL or more natural or legal persons , and , in accordance with national legislation or practice , their associations , organisations or groups , while “ concerned public ” means the public affected or likely to be affected by , or having an interest in , environmental decision - making . For the purposes of this definition , non - governmental organisations promoting environmental protection and meeting any requirements under national law are deemed to have an interest .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL , which deals with public participation in decisions on specific activities , provides as follows :
“ CARDINAL . Each Party :
( a ) Shall apply the provisions of this article with respect to decisions on whether to permit proposed activities listed in annex I ;

( b ) Shall , in accordance with its national law , also apply the provisions of this article to decisions on proposed activities not listed in annex I which may have a significant effect on the environment . To this end , Parties shall determine whether such a proposed activity is subject to these provisions ;

CARDINAL . NORP The public concerned shall be informed , either by public notice or individually as appropriate , early in an environmental decision - making procedure , and in an adequate , timely and effective manner , inter alia , of :
( a ) The proposed activity and the application on which a decision will be taken ;
( b ) The nature of possible decisions or the draft decision ;
( d ) The envisaged procedure , including , as and when this information can be provided :
( i ) The commencement of the procedure ;
( ii ) The opportunities for the public to participate ;

CARDINAL . NORP The public participation procedures shall include reasonable time frames for the different phases , allowing sufficient time for informing the public in accordance with paragraph CARDINAL above and for the public to prepare and participate effectively during the environmental decision - making .
CARDINAL . Each ORG shall provide for early public participation , when all options are open and effective public participation can take place . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL concerns access to justice and provides , inter alia , that :

“ CARDINAL . In addition and without prejudice to the review procedures referred to in DATE and QUANTITY above , each ORG shall ensure that , where they meet the criteria , if any , laid down in its national law , members of the public have access to administrative or judicial procedures to challenge acts and omissions by private persons and public authorities which contravene provisions of its national law relating to the environment .

CARDINAL . NORP In addition and without prejudice to paragraph CARDINAL above , the procedures referred to in DATE , CARDINAL above shall provide adequate and effective remedies , including injunctive relief as appropriate , and be fair , equitable , timely and not prohibitively expensive . Decisions under this article shall be given or recorded in writing . Decisions of courts , and whenever possible of other bodies , shall be publicly accessible . ”

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW on review of compliance requires a meeting of the Parties to establish arrangements for reviewing compliance with LAW A Compliance Committee has been created for that purpose .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG adopted findings and recommendations upon completion of proceedings triggered by a non - governmental organisation that alleged that GPE had failed to comply with its obligations under LAW in connection with the construction of CARDINAL units of a nuclear power plant .

CARDINAL . One of the disputed issues was whether a DATE construction permit was , in fact and substance , a new construction permit or rather , as treated for the purposes of the administrative proceedings at domestic level , an update of a previous construction permit of DATE .
CARDINAL . In paragraph CARDINAL of its report , the ORG stressed that

“ although each ORG is given some discretion in [ these cases ] to determine where public participation is appropriate , the clause “ mutatis mutandis , and where appropriate ” [ used in LAW in relation to the use of the LAW in respect of reconsideration and update of existing operating conditions ] does not imply complete discretion for the ORG concerned to determine whether or not it was appropriate to provide for public participation ” .
CARDINAL . The ORG rather considered , in paragraph CARDINAL of its report , that :

“ the clause ‘ where ORG introduces an objective criterion to be seen in the context of the goals of the Convention , recognizing that ‘ access to information and public participation in decision - making enhance the quality and the implementation of decisions , contribute to public awareness of environmental issues , give the public the opportunity to express its concerns and enable public authorities to take due account of such PERSON and aiming to ‘ further the accountability of and transparency in decision - making and to strengthen public support for decisions on the environment’ . Thus , the clause does not preclude a review by the ORG on whether the above objective criteria were met and whether the ORG concerned should have therefore provided for public participation in the present case . ”
CARDINAL . The ORG found , at paragraph CARDINAL , that :

“ when the authority reconsidered or updated the operating conditions for an activity of such a nature and magnitude , and being the subject of such serious public concern , as this nuclear power plant , with the changes and increased potential impact on the environment as presented to the ORG , public participation would have been appropriate . This conclusion is not countered by the fact that most , if not all , changes in the DATE construction permit lead to stricter requirements than those set in the DATE permit . Thus , by failing to provide for public participation according to article CARDINAL , paragraphs CARDINAL to CARDINAL , the ORG concerned failed to comply with article CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL of the LAW . ”
CARDINAL . NORP However , dealing with a general question of the compatibility of the relevant NORP laws with the Convention , the ORG was unable to
“ conclude that NORP law on public participation and ORG in general also fails to comply with LAW . ”
